canonical_explanation.text: Alcohols, phenols and ethers are important classes of organic compounds containing oxygen. Alcohols (R-OH) have a hydroxyl group bonded to a saturated carbon atom and are classified as primary (1 degree), secondary (2 degree), or tertiary (3 degree) based on the carbon bearing the -OH group. Phenols (Ar-OH) have a hydroxyl group directly attached to an aromatic ring. Ethers (R-O-R') have an oxygen atom bonded to two alkyl or aryl groups. IUPAC nomenclature of alcohols uses the suffix '-ol' with a locant for the -OH position; phenols are named as substituted phenols; ethers are named as alkoxyalkanes. Alcohols are prepared by hydration of alkenes (acid-catalysed, Markovnikov addition), hydroboration-oxidation of alkenes (anti-Markovnikov addition), reduction of carbonyl compounds (NaBH4 or LiAlH4), and Grignard reagent reactions with carbonyl compounds. Physical properties: alcohols and phenols have higher boiling points than hydrocarbons and ethers of comparable molecular mass due to intermolecular hydrogen bonding; solubility in water decreases with increasing hydrocarbon chain length. Reactions of alcohols include dehydration (elimination of water to form alkenes using acid catalyst at high temperature; ease of dehydration: tertiary > secondary > primary, following Zaitsev's rule), oxidation (primary alcohols give aldehydes then carboxylic acids; secondary alcohols give ketones; tertiary alcohols resist oxidation under normal conditions; PCC selectively oxidises primary alcohols to aldehydes), and esterification (reaction with carboxylic acids in the presence of acid catalyst to form esters). Phenols are more acidic than alcohols because the phenoxide ion is stabilised by resonance with the aromatic ring. Electron-withdrawing groups on the ring increase phenol acidity while electron-donating groups decrease it. Phenol reactions include electrophilic aromatic substitution (bromination gives 2,4,6-tribromophenol with Br2/H2O; nitration; sulphonation), Kolbe's reaction (phenoxide + CO2 under pressure gives salicylic acid), Reimer-Tiemann reaction (phenol + CHCl3/NaOH gives salicylaldehyde), and Williamson synthesis to form ethers (phenoxide + alkyl halide). Ethers are prepared by Williamson synthesis (alkoxide or phenoxide + alkyl halide via SN2 mechanism; works best with primary alkyl halides; tertiary halides undergo elimination). Ethers have much lower boiling points than isomeric alcohols because they cannot form hydrogen bonds among themselves. Ether reactions include cleavage by HI (excess HI converts ethers to alkyl iodides) and electrophilic substitution in anisole (methoxy group is activating and ortho/para directing).
rules: Alcohols are classified as primary, secondary or tertiary based on the type of carbon bearing the -OH group.
Boiling points: alcohols > ethers > alkanes of comparable molecular mass, due to hydrogen bonding in alcohols.
Dehydration ease: tertiary alcohol > secondary > primary; follows Zaitsev's rule to give the more substituted alkene.
PCC (pyridinium chlorochromate) oxidises primary alcohols selectively to aldehydes without further oxidation to acids.
Phenols are more acidic than alcohols because the phenoxide ion is resonance-stabilised by delocalisation into the benzene ring.
Kolbe's reaction: sodium phenoxide + CO2 (high pressure, high temperature) gives sodium salicylate, which on acidification gives salicylic acid.
Reimer-Tiemann reaction: phenol + CHCl3 + NaOH gives salicylaldehyde (ortho-hydroxybenzaldehyde) as the major product.
Williamson synthesis: sodium alkoxide + alkyl halide gives ether via SN2; works best with primary halides.
Ethers are cleaved by concentrated HI: R-O-R' + HI gives R-OH + R'-I (or both iodides with excess HI).
The -OCH3 group in anisole is activating and ortho/para directing in electrophilic aromatic substitution.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a tertiary alcohol?
questions.explanation_correct: (CH3)3COH is 2-methylpropan-2-ol (tert-butyl alcohol), a tertiary alcohol because the carbon bearing the -OH group is bonded to three other carbon atoms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CH3CH2OH is a primary alcohol (ethanol), (CH3)2CHOH is a secondary alcohol (propan-2-ol), and C6H5OH is phenol, not an alcohol.

questions.question_text: The IUPAC name of CH3CH(OH)CH3 is:
questions.explanation_correct: The -OH group is on the second carbon of a three-carbon chain, so the IUPAC name is propan-2-ol.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Propan-1-ol has -OH on the first carbon. Isopropanol is a common name, not IUPAC. 2-methylethanol is not a valid name.

questions.question_text: Which method gives an anti-Markovnikov product in the preparation of alcohols from alkenes?
questions.explanation_correct: Hydroboration-oxidation of alkenes adds water in an anti-Markovnikov manner, giving a primary alcohol from a terminal alkene.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Acid-catalysed hydration and oxymercuration-demercuration follow Markovnikov's rule. NaBH4 is used to reduce carbonyl compounds, not for alkene hydration.

questions.question_text: Alcohols have higher boiling points than ethers of comparable molecular mass because:
questions.explanation_correct: Alcohols have an -OH group that can act as both hydrogen bond donor and acceptor, forming strong intermolecular hydrogen bonds that require more energy to break, raising the boiling point.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The question specifies comparable molecular mass, so mass is not the reason. Ethers are covalent, not ionic. Alcohols are polar, not non-polar.

questions.question_text: The reaction of CH3MgBr with methanal (HCHO) followed by acid hydrolysis gives:
questions.explanation_correct: A Grignard reagent (CH3MgBr) adds to formaldehyde (HCHO) to give, after hydrolysis, a primary alcohol with one additional carbon: CH3CH2OH (ethanol).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Methanol would be obtained from HCHO by reduction, not Grignard reaction. Propan-1-ol would require ethanal with CH3MgBr, and propan-2-ol would require propanone with CH3MgBr.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following in decreasing order of boiling points: (I) Butan-1-ol, (II) Butanal, (III) Diethyl ether, (IV) Pentane
questions.explanation_correct: Butan-1-ol (bp 117 degree C) has strongest hydrogen bonding; butanal (bp 75 degree C) has dipole-dipole interactions; diethyl ether (bp 35 degree C) has weaker dipole-dipole; pentane (bp 36 degree C) has only London forces. Correct order: I > II > III > IV (ether and pentane are close, but the overall trend holds).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hydrogen bonding in alcohols makes them highest boiling. Aldehydes have dipole-dipole interactions stronger than the weak van der Waals forces in alkanes and the relatively weak dipole of ethers.

questions.question_text: LiAlH4 can reduce all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation_correct: LiAlH4 is a powerful nucleophilic reducing agent that reduces carbonyl compounds and carboxylic acids to alcohols. However, it does not reduce carbon-carbon double bonds (alkenes) because it acts as a nucleophilic hydride donor, not a hydrogenation catalyst.
questions.explanation_incorrect: LiAlH4 readily reduces aldehydes to primary alcohols, ketones to secondary alcohols, and carboxylic acids to primary alcohols. It cannot reduce C=C bonds; catalytic hydrogenation is needed for that.

questions.question_text: The dehydration of ethanol with concentrated H2SO4 at 443 K gives:
questions.explanation_correct: At 443 K (170 degree C), concentrated H2SO4 causes elimination (intramolecular dehydration) of ethanol to form ethene (CH2=CH2) and water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diethyl ether is formed at lower temperature (413 K / 140 degree C) by intermolecular dehydration. Ethanal requires oxidation, not dehydration. Ethane is not formed under these conditions.

questions.question_text: Which of the following reagents oxidises a primary alcohol to an aldehyde without further oxidation to a carboxylic acid?
questions.explanation_correct: PCC is a mild oxidising agent that selectively oxidises primary alcohols to aldehydes in anhydrous conditions, preventing over-oxidation to carboxylic acids.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Acidified K2Cr2O7 and alkaline KMnO4 are strong oxidising agents that oxidise primary alcohols all the way to carboxylic acids. Concentrated HNO3 is a strong oxidiser not used for selective aldehyde preparation.

questions.question_text: Esterification of ethanol with acetic acid in the presence of concentrated H2SO4 gives:
questions.explanation_correct: Esterification: CH3COOH + C2H5OH (H2SO4 catalyst, reflux) gives CH3COOC2H5 (ethyl acetate) + H2O. This is Fischer esterification.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diethyl ether is formed by dehydration of ethanol at 140 degree C. Acetaldehyde is an oxidation product. Acetic anhydride is formed by different methods, not by esterification.

questions.question_text: Which alcohol undergoes dehydration most easily?
questions.explanation_correct: Ease of dehydration follows the order: tertiary > secondary > primary. 2-Methylpropan-2-ol is a tertiary alcohol and dehydrates most easily because the tertiary carbocation intermediate is the most stable.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Methanol and ethanol are primary alcohols and dehydrate with great difficulty. Propan-2-ol is secondary and dehydrates less easily than a tertiary alcohol.

questions.question_text: Oxidation of propan-2-ol with acidified potassium dichromate gives:
questions.explanation_correct: Propan-2-ol is a secondary alcohol. Oxidation of secondary alcohols gives ketones. Therefore, propan-2-ol is oxidised to propanone (acetone, CH3COCH3).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Propanal would be formed from propan-1-ol. Propanoic acid would require further oxidation of propanal. Secondary alcohols give ketones, which resist further oxidation.

questions.question_text: Dehydration of butan-2-ol with concentrated H2SO4 preferentially gives:
questions.explanation_correct: According to Zaitsev's rule, the major product of dehydration is the more substituted alkene. Butan-2-ol dehydrates to give but-2-ene (more substituted) as the major product over but-1-ene.
questions.explanation_incorrect: But-1-ene is the less substituted alkene and is the minor product by Zaitsev's rule. 2-Methylpropene has a branched skeleton not present in butan-2-ol. Butane is a reduction product, not a dehydration product.

questions.question_text: When 2-methylpropan-2-ol is treated with Cu at 573 K, the product is:
questions.explanation_correct: Tertiary alcohols undergo dehydration (not oxidation) when heated with Cu at 573 K, because there is no hydrogen on the carbon bearing the -OH group. The product is 2-methylpropene.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Primary alcohols give aldehydes and secondary alcohols give ketones with Cu/573 K (catalytic dehydrogenation). Tertiary alcohols lack a hydrogen on the carbinol carbon and instead undergo elimination to give an alkene.

questions.question_text: Which of the following reactions of ethanol is an example of nucleophilic substitution?

options.text: Dehydration with conc. H2SO4 at 443 K
Reaction with HBr in the presence of ZnCl2

questions.explanation_correct: When ethanol reacts with HBr/ZnCl2, the -OH group is replaced by -Br through a nucleophilic substitution mechanism. The bromide ion acts as the nucleophile.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dehydration is an elimination reaction. Reaction with sodium is an acid-base reaction forming sodium ethoxide and H2 gas. Oxidation involves removal of hydrogen atoms.

questions.question_text: The Lucas test (conc. HCl + anhydrous ZnCl2) distinguishes between primary, secondary and tertiary alcohols. A tertiary alcohol reacts:

options.text: Only on prolonged heating for hours

questions.explanation_correct: Tertiary alcohols react immediately with Lucas reagent at room temperature to form the alkyl chloride, which is insoluble and gives turbidity. This is because the tertiary carbocation formed is very stable.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Secondary alcohols react within 5-10 minutes. Primary alcohols react very slowly or only on prolonged heating. All alcohols eventually react; they do not fail to react.

questions.question_text: Phenol is more acidic than ethanol because:

options.text: Phenol has a higher molecular mass
The phenoxide ion is stabilised by resonance with the benzene ring

questions.explanation_correct: When phenol loses a proton, the resulting phenoxide ion is stabilised by delocalisation of the negative charge into the aromatic ring through resonance. This stabilisation is absent in the ethoxide ion, making phenol more acidic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Molecular mass does not directly determine acidity. Hydrogen bonding relates to boiling point, not acidity. Electrophilicity is irrelevant to acid strength.

questions.question_text: When phenol is treated with bromine water, the product is:
questions.explanation_correct: Phenol is highly activated towards electrophilic substitution. With bromine water (Br2/H2O), all three ortho and para positions are brominated to give 2,4,6-tribromophenol as a white precipitate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mono-bromination requires a non-polar solvent like CS2 or CCl4 with Br2. Bromobenzene is formed from benzene, not phenol. Phenol reacts at all available ortho/para positions with bromine water.

questions.question_text: The Kolbe's reaction involves heating sodium phenoxide with CO2 under pressure. The product on acidification is:
questions.explanation_correct: In Kolbe's reaction, sodium phenoxide reacts with CO2 at high temperature and pressure to give sodium salicylate, which on acidification yields salicylic acid (2-hydroxybenzoic acid).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Salicylaldehyde is the product of the Reimer-Tiemann reaction. Benzoic acid is obtained from oxidation of toluene. Phenyl benzoate is an ester, not a product of this reaction.

questions.question_text: In the Reimer-Tiemann reaction, phenol is treated with:
questions.explanation_correct: The Reimer-Tiemann reaction involves treating phenol with chloroform (CHCl3) and aqueous NaOH. The intermediate dichlorocarbene (:CCl2) attacks the ortho position, ultimately giving salicylaldehyde.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CO2/NaOH is the Kolbe's reaction. CCl4 and CH2Cl2 do not generate the dichlorocarbene intermediate needed for this reaction.

questions.question_text: Which of the following phenols is the most acidic?
questions.explanation_correct: The -NO2 group is a strong electron-withdrawing group that stabilises the phenoxide ion through both inductive and resonance effects, making p-nitrophenol the most acidic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electron-donating groups like -CH3 and -OCH3 destabilise the phenoxide ion and decrease acidity. Among the given compounds, only -NO2 increases acidity relative to phenol.

questions.question_text: When phenol reacts with dilute HNO3, the major products are:

options.text: A mixture of ortho- and para-nitrophenol

questions.explanation_correct: The -OH group is an activating, ortho/para directing group. With dilute HNO3, mononitration occurs giving a mixture of ortho-nitrophenol (major at low temperature) and para-nitrophenol.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (picric acid) requires concentrated HNO3 and H2SO4. meta-Nitrophenol is not favoured because -OH directs ortho/para. Nitrobenzene is from nitration of benzene.

questions.question_text: Phenol reacts with aqueous NaOH but ethanol does not dissolve in NaOH solution. This is because:

options.text: Phenol is a stronger acid than ethanol and can donate a proton to NaOH
Ethanol has a higher molecular mass than phenol
NaOH is too weak a base to react with any alcohol

questions.explanation_correct: Phenol (pKa ~ 10) is acidic enough to react with NaOH (a strong base) to form water-soluble sodium phenoxide. Ethanol (pKa ~ 16) is too weakly acidic to react with NaOH.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Molecular mass is not the reason. NaOH reacts with phenol but not aliphatic alcohols due to the difference in acidity. Ethanol does not undergo elimination with NaOH.

questions.question_text: Identify the correct product of the Reimer-Tiemann reaction when phenol is treated with CCl4 and NaOH instead of CHCl3 and NaOH:
questions.explanation_correct: When CCl4 is used instead of CHCl3, trichlorocarbene (:CCl2 is not formed). Instead, a different intermediate leads to the introduction of a -COOH group at the ortho position, producing salicylic acid.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Salicylaldehyde is the product when CHCl3/NaOH is used. Catechol and 2-hydroxyphenyl chloride are not products of this reaction.

questions.question_text: o-Nitrophenol has a lower boiling point than p-nitrophenol because:

options.text: o-Nitrophenol has a higher molecular mass
o-Nitrophenol exhibits intramolecular hydrogen bonding, reducing intermolecular interactions

questions.explanation_correct: In o-nitrophenol, the -OH and -NO2 groups are close enough for intramolecular hydrogen bonding (chelation), which reduces intermolecular hydrogen bonding and lowers the boiling point. p-Nitrophenol has only intermolecular H-bonding, giving it a higher boiling point.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both isomers have the same molecular mass. p-Nitrophenol is actually more associated due to intermolecular H-bonding. Acid strength does not directly determine boiling point.

questions.question_text: Phenol when treated with conc. H2SO4 at different temperatures gives different products. At 298 K the major product is:
questions.explanation_correct: Sulphonation of phenol at low temperature (298 K / 25 degree C) gives the ortho-product as the major product (kinetic control). At higher temperature (373 K / 100 degree C), the para-isomer predominates (thermodynamic control).
questions.explanation_incorrect: p-Hydroxybenzenesulphonic acid is the major product at high temperature, not at 298 K. Disulphonation and simple esterification are not the primary outcomes of this reaction.

questions.question_text: The Williamson synthesis of ethers involves the reaction of:

options.text: An alcohol with H2SO4 at 413 K
A sodium alkoxide with an alkyl halide
An aldehyde with a Grignard reagent

questions.explanation_correct: Williamson synthesis involves an SN2 reaction between a sodium alkoxide (R-O-Na) and a primary alkyl halide (R'-X) to form an ether (R-O-R').
questions.explanation_incorrect: Heating alcohol with H2SO4 at 413 K is a different method of ether synthesis (acid-catalysed dehydration). Sodium metal reacts with alcohols to form alkoxides. Grignard reagents react with aldehydes to form alcohols.

questions.question_text: The IUPAC name of CH3-O-C2H5 is:
questions.explanation_correct: In IUPAC nomenclature, the smaller alkyl group with oxygen is named as an alkoxy substituent on the larger alkane. CH3-O-C2H5 is methoxyethane (methoxy group on ethane).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ethoxymethane would imply an ethoxy group on methane, which is not the standard convention. Methyl ethyl ether is the common name. Ethoxyethane is diethyl ether (C2H5-O-C2H5).

questions.question_text: Ethers have much lower boiling points than isomeric alcohols because:

options.text: Ethers cannot form hydrogen bonds with each other

questions.explanation_correct: Ethers lack an O-H bond and therefore cannot form intermolecular hydrogen bonds among themselves. This results in much weaker intermolecular forces and lower boiling points compared to isomeric alcohols.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The question compares isomeric compounds so molecular masses are the same. Ethers are not completely non-polar (they have a bent C-O-C bond with a dipole moment). Ethers do not decompose at low temperatures.

questions.question_text: When diethyl ether is heated with excess concentrated HI, the products are:

options.text: Two moles of ethyl iodide and water

questions.explanation_correct: With excess HI, both C-O bonds in diethyl ether are cleaved: C2H5-O-C2H5 + 2HI gives 2C2H5I + H2O. The initial ethanol product reacts with excess HI to form ethyl iodide.
questions.explanation_incorrect: With limited HI, one gets ethanol and ethyl iodide, but with excess HI, the ethanol is further converted to ethyl iodide. Ethene would require elimination, not substitution.

questions.question_text: In Williamson synthesis, if tert-butyl bromide is used with sodium ethoxide, the major product is:
questions.explanation_correct: Tertiary alkyl halides undergo elimination (E2) rather than SN2 substitution when treated with a strong base/nucleophile like sodium ethoxide. The major product is 2-methylpropene, not the expected ether.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ethyl tert-butyl ether would be the desired SN2 product but is not formed because tertiary halides favour elimination. Diethyl ether and tert-butanol are not the products of this reaction.

questions.question_text: Electrophilic substitution in anisole (methoxybenzene) occurs preferentially at:
questions.explanation_correct: The -OCH3 group is an electron-donating group through resonance (+M effect). It activates the benzene ring and directs electrophilic substitution to ortho and para positions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Meta direction occurs with electron-withdrawing groups like -NO2 or -COOH. Substitution does not occur exclusively at para or equally at all positions.

questions.question_text: The best way to prepare methyl tert-butyl ether by Williamson synthesis is:
questions.explanation_correct: To avoid elimination, the alkyl halide should be primary. Using sodium tert-butoxide (the bulky alkoxide) with methyl bromide (primary halide) gives the ether via SN2 without significant elimination.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sodium methoxide + tert-butyl bromide would give elimination (E2) as the major reaction. Sodium methoxide + methyl bromide gives dimethyl ether. Sodium tert-butoxide + tert-butyl bromide would also give elimination.

questions.question_text: When anisole is treated with HI, the products are:
questions.explanation_correct: When anisole (C6H5-O-CH3) is cleaved by HI, the C-O bond involving the alkyl group is broken preferentially because iodide attacks the less sterically hindered methyl group via SN2. Products are phenol and CH3I.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The aryl C-O bond (C6H5-O) is much stronger and not broken by HI. Therefore, iodobenzene is not formed. HI cleaves the alkyl-oxygen bond selectively.

questions.question_text: Ethers are generally unreactive. Which property makes them useful as solvents?

options.text: High boiling points due to hydrogen bonding
Chemical inertness combined with ability to solvate cations through lone pairs on oxygen

questions.explanation_correct: Ethers are relatively inert (no reactive O-H bond) but the lone pairs on oxygen can coordinate with cations and Lewis acids. This combination of chemical stability and solvating ability makes them excellent solvents.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ethers do not have H-bonding among themselves and have relatively low boiling points. They are not acids and do not readily polymerise (except cyclic ethers like epoxides).

questions.question_text: Friedel-Crafts acetylation of anisole gives the product predominantly at:
questions.explanation_correct: The -OCH3 group directs to ortho and para positions. However, Friedel-Crafts acylation involves a bulky acylium ion electrophile, and steric effects near the -OCH3 group disfavour the ortho position. The para product (p-methoxyacetophenone) predominates.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Meta substitution would occur with deactivating groups like -NO2. Ortho is disfavoured due to steric hindrance from the incoming bulky acetyl group. The reaction is not non-selective.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about ethers is INCORRECT?

options.text: Ethers are soluble in concentrated H2SO4 due to protonation of oxygen
Ethers form peroxides on prolonged exposure to air and light
Ethers can act as hydrogen bond donors
The C-O-C bond angle in ethers is approximately 110 degrees

questions.explanation_correct: Ethers cannot act as hydrogen bond donors because they lack an O-H or N-H bond. They can only act as hydrogen bond acceptors through the lone pairs on oxygen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ethers dissolve in conc. H2SO4 by forming oxonium ions. They do form explosive peroxides with air. The C-O-C angle is approximately 110 degrees (close to tetrahedral).

questions.question_text: The order of reactivity of alcohols towards sodium metal is:

options.text: All react at the same rate

questions.explanation_correct: Reactivity towards sodium metal depends on the ease of O-H bond cleavage. Primary alcohols are most reactive because they are the most acidic (least steric hindrance, fewer electron-donating alkyl groups destabilising the alkoxide).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tertiary alcohols are least reactive with sodium due to steric hindrance and the destabilising inductive effect of three alkyl groups on the alkoxide. The reactivity is not equal for all types.

questions.question_text: Which of the following reactions is used to distinguish between primary, secondary and tertiary alcohols?
questions.explanation_correct: Victor Meyer's test distinguishes primary, secondary and tertiary alcohols. Primary alcohols give a blood-red colour with FeCl3, secondary give a blue colour, and tertiary give no colour.
questions.explanation_incorrect: All three types of alcohols react with sodium to form alkoxides (the rate differs but is not a clear distinction test). H2SO4 causes dehydration. Acetyl chloride forms esters with all types.

questions.question_text: Ethanol reacts with acetic acid in the presence of concentrated H2SO4 to form ethyl acetate. This reaction is called:
questions.explanation_correct: The reaction between an alcohol and a carboxylic acid in the presence of an acid catalyst to form an ester and water is called esterification (Fischer esterification).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Saponification is the hydrolysis of an ester with NaOH. Dehydration refers to the removal of water from an alcohol to form alkene or ether. Hydrolysis is the reverse of esterification.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following in increasing order of acidity: (I) Ethanol, (II) Phenol, (III) p-nitrophenol, (IV) Water
questions.explanation_correct: Acidity order: ethanol (pKa ~ 16) < water (pKa ~ 15.7) < phenol (pKa ~ 10) < p-nitrophenol (pKa ~ 7.2). The electron-withdrawing -NO2 group greatly stabilises the phenoxide ion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ethanol is less acidic than water due to the electron-donating alkyl group. Phenol is far more acidic than water due to resonance stabilisation of phenoxide. p-Nitrophenol is the most acidic due to the -NO2 group.

questions.question_text: When ethanol reacts with SOCl2 (thionyl chloride), the products are:
questions.explanation_correct: C2H5OH + SOCl2 gives C2H5Cl + SO2 + HCl. This is a preferred method for converting alcohols to alkyl chlorides because both by-products (SO2 and HCl) are gases and escape, driving the reaction to completion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The reaction gives gaseous by-products (SO2 and HCl), not H2SO3. Ethene formation would require elimination. Ether formation does not occur with SOCl2.

questions.question_text: Phenol gives a characteristic violet colour with:
questions.explanation_correct: Phenol reacts with neutral ferric chloride (FeCl3) solution to give a characteristic violet (or purple) colour due to the formation of a ferric phenoxide complex [Fe(OC6H5)6]3-.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sodium reacts with phenol to produce H2 gas. Bromine water gives a white precipitate of 2,4,6-tribromophenol. Concentrated H2SO4 causes sulphonation.

questions.question_text: Diethyl ether can be prepared by heating ethanol with concentrated H2SO4 at:
questions.explanation_correct: At 413 K (140 degree C), ethanol undergoes intermolecular dehydration with conc. H2SO4 to form diethyl ether. At higher temperature (443 K), intramolecular dehydration occurs giving ethene.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 443 K gives ethene (intramolecular dehydration). 373 K is not the optimal temperature for ether formation. 573 K is too high and would give decomposition products.

questions.question_text: Which of the following alcohols will give a positive iodoform test?
questions.explanation_correct: Ethanol has the structural unit CH3CH(OH)- needed for the iodoform test. Ethanol is first oxidised to acetaldehyde (CH3CHO), which then reacts with I2/NaOH to form CHI3 (iodoform, yellow precipitate).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Methanol lacks the CH3CH(OH) or CH3CO group required. Propan-1-ol and 2-methylpropan-1-ol also do not have this structural feature and give negative iodoform tests.

questions.question_text: Catalytic dehydrogenation of propan-1-ol over Cu at 573 K gives:
questions.explanation_correct: Primary alcohols undergo catalytic dehydrogenation (loss of H2) over copper at 573 K to form aldehydes. Propan-1-ol (CH3CH2CH2OH) gives propanal (CH3CH2CHO).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Propanone is formed from propan-2-ol (secondary). Propanoic acid requires stronger oxidation. Propene would be formed by dehydration (elimination), not dehydrogenation.

questions.question_text: Phenol is less acidic than which of the following?
questions.explanation_correct: Carbonic acid (pKa ~ 6.4) is a stronger acid than phenol (pKa ~ 10). This is why sodium phenoxide reacts with CO2 + H2O to regenerate phenol (the stronger acid displaces the weaker from its salt).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ethanol (pKa ~ 16), water (pKa ~ 15.7), and methanol (pKa ~ 15.5) are all less acidic than phenol (pKa ~ 10).

questions.question_text: Crown ethers are cyclic ethers that are used to:

options.text: Complex with alkali metal cations and carry them into organic solvents

questions.explanation_correct: Crown ethers are macrocyclic polyethers with a central cavity that can selectively bind alkali metal cations (through ion-dipole interactions with oxygen lone pairs), making them soluble in organic solvents. This is used in phase-transfer catalysis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Crown ethers are not catalysts for electrophilic substitution, not reducing agents, and not involved in polymerisation. Their primary function is cation complexation.

questions.question_text: Which reagent is used to convert an alcohol to an alkyl halide in one step with gaseous by-products only?
questions.explanation_correct: SOCl2 converts alcohols to alkyl chlorides with SO2 and HCl as gaseous by-products. This is advantageous because the products do not need purification from liquid or solid by-products.
questions.explanation_incorrect: HCl/ZnCl2 gives HCl and ZnCl2 residues. PCl5 gives POCl3 (liquid) and HCl. PBr3 gives H3PO3 (non-gaseous). Only SOCl2 gives exclusively gaseous by-products.

questions.question_text: Which phenol derivative is obtained when phenol is treated with phthalic anhydride in the presence of concentrated H2SO4?
questions.explanation_correct: When phenol reacts with phthalic anhydride in the presence of conc. H2SO4, phenolphthalein is formed. Phenolphthalein is a well-known acid-base indicator that is colourless in acid and pink in base.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Salicylic acid is formed by Kolbe's reaction. Bakelite is formed from phenol and formaldehyde. Aspirin is acetylsalicylic acid, not a product of phenol with phthalic anhydride.
